an11.13:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, near Kapilavatthu in the Banyan Tree Monastery.
an11.13:1.2: Now at that time the Buddha wanted to commence the rains residence at Sāvatthī.
an11.13:2.1: Nandiya the Sakyan heard about this,
an11.13:2.4: “Why don’t I also commence the rains residence at Sāvatthī.
an11.13:2.5: There I can apply myself to my work and from time to time get to see the Buddha.”
an11.13:3.1: So the Buddha commenced the rains residence in Sāvatthī,
an11.13:3.3: There he applied himself to his work and from time to time got to see the Buddha.
an11.13:3.4: At that time several mendicants were making a robe for the Buddha, thinking that
an11.13:3.5: when his robe was finished and the three months of the rains residence had passed the Buddha would set out wandering.
an11.13:4.1: Nandiya the Sakyan heard about this.
an11.13:4.4: He went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:
an11.13:4.6: several mendicants are making a robe for the Buddha, thinking that
an11.13:4.7: when his robe was finished and the three months of the rains residence had passed the Buddha would set out wandering.
an11.13:4.8: Now, we spend our life in various ways. Which of these should we practice?”
an11.13:5.2: It’s appropriate that gentlemen such as you come to me and ask:
an11.13:5.3: ‘We spend our life in various ways. Which of these should we practice?’
an11.13:5.4: The faithful succeed, not the faithless.
an11.13:5.5: The ethical succeed, not the unethical.
an11.13:5.6: The energetic succeed, not the lazy.
an11.13:5.7: The mindful succeed, not the unmindful.
an11.13:5.8: Those with immersion succeed, not those without immersion.
an11.13:5.9: The wise succeed, not the witless.
an11.13:5.10: When you’re grounded on these six things, go on to develop five further things.
an11.13:6.1: Firstly, you should recollect the Realized One:
an11.13:6.2: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
an11.13:6.3: In this way you should establish mindfulness internally based on the Realized One.
an11.13:7.1: Furthermore, you should recollect the teaching:
an11.13:7.2: ‘The teaching is well explained by the Buddha—visible in this very life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.’
an11.13:7.3: In this way you should establish mindfulness internally based on the teaching.
an11.13:8.1: Furthermore, you should recollect your good friends:
an11.13:8.3: to have good friends who advise and instruct me out of kindness and compassion.’
an11.13:8.4: In this way you should establish mindfulness internally based on good friends.
an11.13:9.1: Furthermore, you should recollect your own generosity:
an11.13:9.3: Among people with hearts full of the stain of stinginess I live at home rid of stinginess, freely generous, open-handed, loving to let go, committed to charity, loving to give and to share.’
an11.13:9.4: In this way you should establish mindfulness internally based on generosity.
an11.13:10.1: Furthermore, you should recollect the deities:
an11.13:10.2: ‘There are deities who, surpassing the company of deities that consume solid food, are reborn in a certain host of mind-made deities. They don’t see in themselves anything more to do, or anything that needs improvement.’
an11.13:10.3: An irreversibly freed mendicant doesn’t see in themselves anything more to do, or anything that needs improvement.
an11.13:10.4: In the same way, Nandiya, there are deities who, surpassing the company of deities that consume solid food, are reborn in a certain host of mind-made deities. They don’t see in themselves anything more to do, or anything that needs improvement.
an11.13:10.5: In this way you should establish mindfulness internally based on the deities.
an11.13:11.1: A noble disciple who has these eleven qualities gives up bad, unskillful qualities and doesn’t cling to them.
an11.13:11.2: It’s like when a pot full of water is tipped over, so the water drains out and doesn’t go back in.
an11.13:11.3: Suppose there was an uncontrolled fire. It advances burning up dry woodlands and doesn’t go back over what it has burned.
an11.13:11.4: In the same way, a noble disciple who has these eleven qualities gives up bad, unskillful qualities and doesn’t cling to them.”
